You can fetch a max of 25 entities in one query.

For more details on entities, visit our [entity docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/graphql-api/tutorials/use-new-relic-graphql-api-query-entities).

args.name: guids

fields.name: entity

Fetch a single entity.

args.name: guid
args.description: A unique entity identifier.

fields.name: entitySearch
fields.description:
Search for entities using a custom query.

For more details on how to create a custom query
and what entity data you can request, visit our
[entity docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/graphql-api/tutorials/use-new-relic-graphql-api-query-entities).

Note: you must supply either a `query` OR a `queryBuilder` argument, not both.

args.name: options
args.description: Additional options to apply to the entity search.

args.name: query
args.description:
Entity search query string.
The query string can search for an exact or fuzzy match on name, as well as searching several other attributes.

Note: you must supply either a `query` OR a `queryBuilder` argument, not both.

Operators available: `=`, `AND`, `IN`, `LIKE`

Special characters (`.,;:*-_`) are treated as whitespace. For example, name LIKE ':aws:' will match `-aws.` or `foo aws.`

Tags can be referenced in multiple ways with or without backticks.

Examples:
- `"name = 'MyApp (Staging)'`
- `"name LIKE 'MyApp' AND type IN ('APPLICATION')"`
- `"reporting = 'false' AND type IN ('HOST')"`
- `"domain IN ('INFRA', 'APM')"`
- `tags.Environment = 'staging' AND type IN ('APPLICATION')`

args.name: queryBuilder
args.description:
The query builder object can be used to discover and create the entity search query argument.

This should be used as a means to discover, but it has limited functionality. For example, it can only search for one entity `type` at a time.

The `queryBuilder` parameters do not include all possible entity `type`s, entity `domain`s, or `infrastructureIntegrationType`s.

To see the query string that is generated by your `queryBuilder` search, ask for the `query` field in the result object. You can then use this to build a more complex query supplied to the `query` argument and remove your `queryBuilder`.

Note: you must supply either a `query` OR a `queryBuilder` argument, not both.

args.name: sortBy
args.description: The criteria used to sort your entity search results.

fields.name: nerdStorage
fields.description:
NerdStorage is a document database that is accessible within the New Relic One interface.
This allows for persistence of Nerdpack data including users' configuration settings and preferences
(like favorites), or any other small data sets.

Conceptually, you can imagine NerdStorage as a nested key-value map.

For information on New Relic NerdStorage, visit [our docs](https://developer.newrelic.com/build-tools/new-relic-one-applications/nerdstorage).

To use the NerdStorage schema you must specify a Nerdpack ID using the NewRelic-Package-Id header in your request.

fields.name: nrql
fields.description:
Make a query to NRDB with a NRQL string.

See the [NRQL Docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/insights/nrql-new-relic-query-language/nrql-resources/nrql-syntax-components-functions) for more information about generating a query string.

Example NRQL query:
```
SELECT count(*) FROM Transaction TIMESERIES
```

For more details on how to use NRQL in the GraphQL API, visit [our docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/graphql-api/tutorials/query-nrql-through-new-relic-graphql-api)

args.name: accounts
args.description: List of account IDs to return NRDB results from. Max of 5 can be supplied.

args.name: async
args.description:
When true, the query will begin asynchronous resolution after the allotted `timeout`. Include `queryProgress` fields in your GraphQL query to receive the information you will need to poll the `nrqlQueryProgress` field for the results of your async NRQL query.

See [this page](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/nerdgraph/examples/async-queries-nrql-tutorial) for additional asynchronous query documentation.

args.name: options
args.description: Additional options for NRQL queries.

args.name: query
args.description: The [NRQL](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/insights/nrql-new-relic-query-language/nrql-resources/nrql-syntax-components-functions) query string.

args.name: timeout
args.description:
The timeout we will apply to the NRQL Query. The value will be clamped to between 5 and 120 seconds and defaults to 5 seconds.

For `async` queries, if the query is still incomplete after this amount of time, resolution will become asynchronous and return `queryProgress` data if requested.

fields.name: nrqlQueryHistory
fields.description: A historical log of NRQL queries executed by you.

fields.name: nrqlQueryProgress
fields.description:
Poll for the results of a previously-executed asychronous NRDB query.

The `queryId` is available in the `queryProgress` data returned by the original asynchronous query.

See [this page](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/nerdgraph/examples/async-queries-nrql-tutorial) for additional asynchronous query documentation.

args.name: accounts
args.description: List of account IDs associated with `queryId`. Must match the account IDs of the original asynchronous query. Max of 5 can be supplied.

args.name: queryId
args.description: A token for retrieving the results of a previously executed asynchronous query.

fields.name: attribute
fields.description:
The attribute on a violation. Expects one of:

* **accountId** - The account id
* **conditionId** - The alert condition id
* **conditionName** - The alert condition name
* **conditionRunbookUrl** - The alert condition's runbook url
* **conditionType** - The alert condition type, such as `metric`
* **entity.guid** - The entity GUID
* **nrqlEventType** - The NRQL event type
* **nrqlQuery** - The NRQL query string
* **policyId** - The alert policy id
* **policyName** - The alert policy name
* **product** - The target product (e.g., `SYNTHETICS`)
* **tags.<NAME>** - Arbitrary tags associated with some entity (e.g., FACET from a NRQL query, for example `tags.appName` or `tags.host`)
* **targetId** - The ID of the alerts target
* **targetName** - The name of the alerts target

fields.name: values
fields.description: The value(s) to compare against the attribute's value.

types.name: AlertsMutingRuleSchedule
types.description: The time window when the MutingRule should actively mute violations.

fields.name: endRepeat
fields.description:
The datetime stamp when the MutingRule schedule should stop repeating.
This is in ISO 8601 format with offset.

Example: `'2020-07-10T15:00:00-07:00'`

Note: Either `endRepeat` or `repeatCount` should be used to end a MutingRule schedule.
Both fields should not be provided together.

fields.name: endTime
fields.description:
The datetime stamp representing when the MutingRule should end.
This is in ISO 8601 format with offset.

Example: `'2020-07-10T15:00:00-07:00'`

fields.name: nextEndTime
fields.description:
The datetime stamp representing the next scheduled end of a recurring MutingRule.
This is in ISO 8601 format with offset.

Example: `'2020-07-08T14:30:00-07:00'`

Note: If a MutingRule is not set to recur, this will match the `endTime` field.

fields.name: nextStartTime
fields.description:
The datetime stamp representing the next scheduled start of a recurring MutingRule.
This is in ISO 8601 format with offset.

Example: `'2020-07-08T14:30:00-07:00'`

Note: If a MutingRule is not set to recur, this will match the `startTime` field.

fields.name: repeat
fields.description:
The frequency the MutingRule schedule repeats.
If the MutingRule repeats `WEEKLY`, be sure to set `weeklyRepeatDays`.
If the MutingRule does not repeat, use `null`.

Example: `DAILY`

fields.name: repeatCount
fields.description:
The number of times the MutingRule schedule should repeat.

Note: Either `repeatCount` or `endRepeat` should be used to end a MutingRule schedule.
Both fields should not be provided together.

fields.name: startTime
fields.description:
The datetime stamp representing when the MutingRule should start.
This is in ISO 8601 format with offset.

Example: `'2020-07-08T14:30:00-07:00'`

fields.name: timeZone
fields.description:
The time zone that applies to the MutingRule schedule.

Example: `'America/Los_Angeles'`

See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tz_database_time_zones.

fields.name: weeklyRepeatDays
fields.description:
The day(s) of the week that a MutingRule should repeat when the repeat field is set to `WEEKLY`.

Example: `[MONDAY, WEDNESDAY]`

types.name: AlertsMutingRuleScheduleRepeat
types.description: Details about if or how frequently a MutingRule's schedule repeats.

enumValues.name: DAILY
enumValues.description: Schedule repeats once per calendar day

enumValues.name: MONTHLY
enumValues.description: Schedule repeats once per calendar month

enumValues.name: WEEKLY
enumValues.description: Schedule repeats once per specified day per calendar week

types.name: AlertsDayOfWeek
types.description: The day of the week used to configure a WEEKLY scheduled MutingRule

types.name: AlertsMutingRuleStatus
types.description: The status of a MutingRule based on whether it is Enabled and has a Schedule

enumValues.name: ENDED
enumValues.description: Muting is enabled, but no longer active (there's no future schedule).

enumValues.name: SCHEDULED
enumValues.description: Muting is enabled but not active yet (there's a future schedule).

types.name: AlertsNrqlConditionExpiration
types.description: Settings for how violations are opened or closed when a signal expires.

fields.name: closeViolationsOnExpiration
fields.description: Whether to close all open violations when the signal expires. Defaults to true.

fields.name: expirationDuration

fields.name: openViolationOnExpiration

types.name: AlertsNrqlConditionQuery
types.description:
Information for generating the condition NRQL query.
Output from the evaluated NRQL query will be compared to the condition terms to detect violations.

fields.name: evaluationOffset
fields.description:
Deprecated; superseded by `signal.aggregationMethod` with `signal.aggregationDelay` or `signal.aggregationTimer`.

By default, we evaluate the NRQL query in one-minute time windows. The start time depends on the value you select in the NRQL condition's `evaluationOffset`. Evaluation offset cannot be greater than 60 minutes.

This value is the number of time windows we look back at the aggregated data.

Example: With an `evaluationOffset` of 3, the NRQL time window applied to your query will be:

`SINCE 3 minutes ago UNTIL 2 minutes ago`
fields.deprecationReason: Superseded by `signal.aggregationMethod` with `signal.aggregationDelay` or `signal.aggregationTimer`.

fields.name: query
fields.description: NRQL syntax that defines the query.

types.name: AlertsNrqlConditionSignal
types.description: Configuration that defines the signal that the NRQL condition will use to evaluate.

fields.name: aggregationDelay
fields.description:
How long we wait for data that belongs in each aggregation window. Depending
on your data, a longer delay may increase accuracy but delay notifications.

Use `aggregationDelay` with the `EVENT_FLOW` and `CADENCE` methods. The maximum
delay is **1200 seconds** (20 minutes) when using `EVENT_FLOW` and **3600 seconds**
(60 minutes) when using `CADENCE`. In both cases, the minimum delay is **0 seconds**
and the default is **120 seconds**.

fields.name: aggregationMethod
fields.description:
The method that determines when we consider an aggregation window to be complete
so that we can evaluate the signal for violations. Default is `EVENT_FLOW`.

fields.name: aggregationTimer
fields.description:
How long we wait after each data point arrives to make sure we've processed
the whole batch.

Use `aggregationTimer` with the `EVENT_TIMER` method. The timer value can range
from **5 seconds** to **1200 seconds** (20 minutes); the default is **60 seconds**.

fields.name: aggregationWindow
fields.description:
Aggregation window controls the duration of the time window used to evaluate the NRQL query, in seconds.
The value must be at least 30 seconds, and no more than 15 minutes (900 seconds). Default is 60 seconds.

fields.name: evaluationOffset
fields.description:
Deprecated; superseded by `signal.aggregationMethod` with `signal.aggregationDelay` or `signal.aggregationTimer`.

By default, we evaluate the NRQL query in one-minute time windows. The start time depends on the value you select in the NRQL condition's `evaluationOffset`. Evaluation offset cannot be greater than 60 minutes.

This value is the number of time windows we look back at the aggregated data.

Example: With an `evaluationOffset` of 3 and a 1 minute aggregation window, the NRQL time window applied to your query will be:

`SINCE 3 minutes ago UNTIL 2 minutes ago`
fields.deprecationReason: Superseded by `signal.aggregationMethod` with `signal.aggregationDelay` or `signal.aggregationTimer`.

fields.name: fillOption
fields.description:
Option that determines the type of value that should be used to fill gaps (empty windows). Defaults to STATIC.

Outlier NRQL conditions may only use NONE.

fields.name: fillValue
fields.description: If using the static fill option, this the value used for filling. Defaults to 0.

fields.name: slideBy
fields.description:
This setting gathers data in overlapping time windows to smooth the chart line, making it easier to spot trends.

Not used for Outlier NRQL conditions.

types.name: AlertsSignalAggregationMethod
types.description:
The method that determines when we consider an aggregation window to be complete
so that we can evaluate the signal for violations. Default is `CADENCE`.

enumValues.name: CADENCE
enumValues.description:
`CADENCE` streams data points as the clocks at New Relic advance past the end
of their window. This ensures a rigorous evaluation cadence, but does not take
into account extraneous data latency.

Use in conjunction with the `aggregationDelay` field.

enumValues.name: EVENT_FLOW
enumValues.description:
`EVENT_FLOW` streams data points for evaluation as data for newer time windows
arrive. Whenever data is received, any data points older than the specified
delay will be evaluated.

Use in conjunction with the `aggregationDelay` field.

enumValues.name: EVENT_TIMER
enumValues.description:
`EVENT_TIMER` streams data points after the specified timer elapses since data
last arrived for that window. Special measures are taken to make sure data
points flow in order.

Use in conjunction with the `aggregationTimer` field.

types.name: AlertsFillOption
types.description: The available fill options.

enumValues.name: LAST_VALUE
enumValues.description: Fill using the last known value.

types.name: AlertsNrqlConditionTerms

fields.description: Operator used to compare against the threshold.

fields.name: priority
fields.description: Priority determines whether notifications will be sent for violations or not.

fields.name: threshold
fields.description: Value that triggers a violation.

fields.name: thresholdDuration
fields.description: Duration, in seconds, that the condition must violate the threshold before creating a violation.

fields.name: thresholdOccurrences
fields.description: How many data points must be in violation for the specified threshold duration.

types.name: AlertsNrqlConditionTermsOperator
types.description: Operator used to compare against the threshold for NrqlConditions.

enumValues.name: ABOVE
enumValues.description: For comparing values above a threshold.

enumValues.name: ABOVE_OR_EQUALS
enumValues.description: For comparing values above or equal to a threshold.

enumValues.name: BELOW
enumValues.description: For comparing values below a threshold.

enumValues.name: BELOW_OR_EQUALS
enumValues.description: For comparing values below or equal to a threshold.

enumValues.name: EQUALS
enumValues.description: For comparing values equal to a threshold.

enumValues.name: NOT_EQUALS
enumValues.description: For comparing values that do not equal a threshold.

types.name: AlertsNrqlConditionPriority
types.description: Value determining whether to open a critical or warning violation for a NrqlCondition.

enumValues.name: CRITICAL
enumValues.description: When a critical priority violation occurs, notifications will be sent. The number of incidents opened and notifications sent depends on the incident preference defined in the condition's policy.

enumValues.name: WARNING
enumValues.description: Does not generate notifications. Use a warning priority when you want to monitor when a system behavior is concerning or noteworthy, but not important enough to require a notification.

types.name: AlertsNrqlConditionThresholdOccurrences
types.description: How many data points must be in violation for a NrqlCondition term's threshold duration.

enumValues.name: ALL
enumValues.description: All points must be in violation during a term's threshold duration.

fields.description: Determines how incidents are created for critical violations of the conditions contained in the policy.

fields.description: Description of the policy.

types.name: AlertsIncidentPreference
types.description: Determines how incidents are created for critical violations of the conditions contained in the policy.

enumValues.name: PER_CONDITION
enumValues.description:
A condition will create a condition-level incident when it violates its critical threshold.
Other violating conditions will create their own incidents.

enumValues.name: PER_CONDITION_AND_TARGET
enumValues.description:
Each target of each condition will create an entity-level incident upon critical violation.
Other violating targets will create their own incidents (even on the same condition).

enumValues.name: PER_POLICY
enumValues.description:
A condition will create a policy-level incident when it violates its critical threshold.
Other violating conditions will be grouped into this incident.

- Recipe events are used in the nr1-install-newrelic nerdlet to provide an overview of all the attempted installation statuses.

types.name: NrqlQueryOptions
types.description: Additional options for NRQL queries.

inputFields.name: eventNamespaces
inputFields.description:
Limit the NRQL query to return results from the chosen Event Namespaces.

You must supply at least 1 valid event namespace when using this option.
Invalid event namespaces will be filtered out.

If omitted, the default list will be `["Default"]`

For more details about Event Namespaces, visit our [docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/accounts/new-relic-account-usage/getting-started-usage/insights-subscription-usage/#namespace).

types.name: NrdbResultContainer
types.description:
A data structure that contains the results of the NRDB query along
with other capabilities that enhance those results.

Direct query results are available through `results`, `totalResult` and
`otherResult`. The query you made is accessible through `nrql`, along with
`metadata` about the query itself. Enhanced capabilities include
`eventDefinitions`, `suggestedFacets` and more.

fields.name: currentResults
fields.description: In a `COMPARE WITH` query, the `currentResults` contain the results for the current comparison time window.

fields.name: embeddedChartUrl
fields.description:
Generate a publicly sharable Embedded Chart URL for the NRQL query.

For more details, see [our docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/graphql-api/tutorials/query-nrql-through-new-relic-graphql-api#embeddable-charts).

args.name: chartType
args.description:
The type of chart visualization you want rendered.

We will default to the best fit for the provided NRQL query if omitted.

fields.name: eventDefinitions
fields.description:
Retrieve a list of event type definitions, providing descriptions
of the event types returned by this query, as well as details
of their attributes.

fields.name: metadata
fields.description: Metadata about the query and result.

fields.name: nrql
fields.description: The [NRQL](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/insights/nrql-new-relic-query-language/nrql-resources/nrql-syntax-components-functions) query that was executed to yield these results.

fields.name: otherResult
fields.description:
In a `FACET` query, the `otherResult` contains the aggregates representing the events _not_
contained in an individual `results` facet.

fields.name: previousResults
fields.description: In a `COMPARE WITH` query, the `previousResults` contain the results for the previous comparison time window.

fields.name: queryProgress
fields.description: Metadata about the execution of an asynchronous NRQL query.

fields.name: rawResponse
fields.description: The raw query results exactly as they are returned from NRDB. NerdGraph provides no additional transformation.

fields.name: results
fields.description: The query results. This is a flat list of objects who's structure matches the query submitted.

fields.name: staticChartUrl
fields.description: Generate a publicly sharable static chart URL for the NRQL query.

args.name: chartType
args.description:
The type of static chart visualization you want rendered.

We will default to the best fit for the provided NRQL query if omitted.

args.name: format
args.description: The type of static chart format you want rendered.

args.name: height
args.description: The height of static chart format you want rendered.

args.name: width
args.description: The width of static chart format you want rendered.

fields.name: suggestedFacets
fields.description:
Retrieve a list of suggested NRQL facets for this NRDB query, to be used with
the `FACET` keyword in NRQL.

Results are based on historical query behaviors.

If the query already has a `FACET` clause, it will be ignored for the purposes
of suggesting facets.

For more details, see [our docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/graphql-api/tutorials/nerdgraph-graphiql-nrql-tutorial#suggest-facets).

fields.name: suggestedQueries
fields.description:
Suggested queries that could help explain an anomaly in your timeseries based on either statistical differences in the data or historical usage.

If no `anomalyTimeWindow` is supplied, we will attempt to detect a spike in the NRQL results. If no spike is found, the suggested query results will be empty.

Input NRQL must be a TIMESERIES query and must have exactly one result.

args.name: anomalyTimeWindow
args.description: The time window of a specific anomaly in milliseconds since Epoch time.

fields.name: totalResult
fields.description:
In a `FACET` query, the `totalResult` contains the aggregates representing _all_ the events,
whether or not they are contained in an individual `results` facet.

enumValues.name: WORST_STATUS_WINS
enumValues.description: The group status matches the most critical status of all belonging entities.

enumValues.description: The worst status is rolled up only after a certain percentage of entities within the workload are not operational.

args.description: Unique identifier shared by all spans within a single trace.

types.name: DistributedTracingTrace
types.description: A collection of spans with context describing those spans.  The trace represents the complete processing of a request.

fields.name: backendDurationMs
fields.description: The duration in milliseconds for the back-end part of this trace (not from a client such as a Browser application)

fields.name: durationMs
fields.description: The total duration of this trace in milliseconds.

fields.name: entities
fields.description: All entities that are part of this trace.

fields.name: entityCount
fields.description: The number of entities that are part of this trace.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Unique identifier for this trace.

fields.name: spanConnections
fields.description: Parent/child IDs that represent all of the span relationships within this trace.

fields.name: spans
fields.description: Spans associated with this trace. The maximum number of spans returned is limited to 10_000. This could be less than the actual number of spans sent for the trace.

fields.name: timestamp
fields.description: Epoch milliseconds timestamp represents this trace's start time.

types.name: DistributedTracingSpanConnection
types.description: A relationship between a parent and child span.

fields.name: child
fields.description: The span identifier of the child for this connection.

fields.name: parent
fields.description: The span identifier of the parent for this connection.

types.name: DistributedTracingSpan
types.description: The primary building block of a distributed trace.  An individual unit of work.

fields.name: attributes
fields.description: All attributes for this span. This field is a map of string keys to attributes values.

fields.name: clientType
fields.description: When the span represents a call to another entity, clientType indicates the type of the entity that was called.

fields.name: durationMs
fields.description: The duration of this span in milliseconds.

fields.name: entityGuid
fields.description: Unique identifier for the entity that created this span. This value has a corresponding entry in the entities field of the trace.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Unique identifier for this span.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The name of this span.

fields.name: parentId
fields.description: The identifier of the caller of this span (null if this is the root span).

fields.name: processBoundary
fields.description: The position of a span with respect to the boundaries between processes in the trace.

fields.name: spanAnomalies
fields.description: Anomalies detected for this span, compared to similar spans that occurred over the previous hours before this span occurred.

fields.name: timestamp
fields.description: Epoch milliseconds timestamp represents this span's start time.

fields.name: traceId
fields.description: Unique identifier shared by all spans within a single trace.

types.name: DistributedTracingSpanAttributes
types.description: Map of key value pairs for a span

types.name: DistributedTracingSpanClientType
types.description: Represents whether a span is a call to a datastore or an external service.

enumValues.name: DATASTORE
enumValues.description: A span that represents a call to a datastore.

enumValues.name: EXTERNAL
enumValues.description: A span that represents a call to an external service.

types.name: DistributedTracingSpanProcessBoundary
types.description: The position of a span with respect to the boundaries between processes in the trace.

enumValues.name: ENTRY
enumValues.description: The first span in a process.

enumValues.name: EXIT
enumValues.description: A span that is the parent of an ENTRY span, or has an attribute name prefixed with either `db.` or `http.`, such as `db.statement` or `http.url`. If a span is both the first span in its process and has a `db.` or `http.`, its processBoundary value will be ENTRY.

enumValues.name: IN_PROCESS
enumValues.description: A span that is neither an ENTRY nor EXIT span. In-process spans are operations within each process, like internal method calls and functions.

types.name: DistributedTracingSpanAnomaly
types.description: An anomaly detected with respect to an attribute of a span.

fields.name: anomalousValue
fields.description: The value of the span attribute which was detected as being anomalous.

fields.name: anomalyType
fields.description: The attribute of the span which was detected as being anomalous.

fields.name: averageMeasure
fields.description: The average value for the attribute on similar spans.

types.name: DistributedTracingSpanAnomalyType
types.description: The type of Span Anomaly being reported (currently only Duration is supported).

enumValues.name: DURATION
enumValues.description: An anomaly type related to the duration of the span.

fields.name: nrdbQuery
fields.description:
Make an `Entity` scoped query to NRDB with a NRQL string.

A relevant `WHERE` clause will be added to your query to scope data to the entity in question.

See the [NRQL Docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/insights/nrql-new-relic-query-language/nrql-resources/nrql-syntax-components-functions) for more information about generating a query string.

args.name: async
args.description:
When true, the query will begin asynchronous resolution after the allotted `timeout`. Include `queryProgress` fields in your GraphQL query to receive the information you will need to poll the `nrdbQueryProgress` field for the results of your async NRQL query.

See [this page](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/nerdgraph/examples/async-queries-nrql-tutorial) for additional asynchronous query documentation.

args.name: nrql
args.description: The [NRQL](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/insights/nrql-new-relic-query-language/nrql-resources/nrql-syntax-components-functions) query string.

args.name: options
args.description: Additional options for NRQL queries.

args.name: timeout
args.description:
The timeout we will apply to the NRQL Query. The value will be clamped to between 5 and 120 seconds and defaults to 5 seconds.

For `async` queries, if the query is still incomplete after this amount of time, resolution will become asynchronous and return `queryProgress` data if requested.

fields.name: nrdbQueryProgress
fields.description:
Poll for the results of a previously-executed asychronous NRDB query.

The `queryId` is available in the `queryProgress` data returned by the original asynchronous query.

See [this page](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/nerdgraph/examples/async-queries-nrql-tutorial) for additional asynchronous query documentation.

args.name: queryId
args.description: A token for retrieving the results of a previously executed asynchronous query.

fields.deprecationReason: This field is experimental! It may change at any time.

fields.name: permalink
fields.description: The url to the entity.

fields.name: recentAlertViolations
fields.description: Recent violations on the entity.

args.name: count
args.description: The desired number of alert violations to be returned.

fields.name: relatedEntities

types.name: EntitySearch
types.description:
A data structure that contains the detailed response of an entity search.

The direct search result is available through `results`. Information about the
query itself is available through `query`, `types`, and `count`.

fields.name: count
fields.description: The number of entities returned by the entity search.

fields.name: counts
fields.description:
A count of the Entity Search results faceted by a chosen set of criteria.

Note: Unlike a NRQL facet, the facet results do not include entities where the facet value does not exist. Additionally, entities can be tagged with multiple tag values for one tag key. For these reasons, depending on the facet values chosen, the `counts` field will not always equal the `entitySearch.count` field.

args.name: facet
args.description:
A list of criteria to facet entities by.

This can be combined with the `facetTags` argument to facet by a combination of criteria and tags.

args.name: facetTags
args.description:
A list of tags to facet entities by. For example: `"environment"`, `"region"`.

This can be combined with the `facet` argument to facet by a combination of criteria and tags.

Note: If a tag does not exist on an entity, the entity will not be counted in the facet results. If an entity tag has multiple values, it will be counted in all facets that apply.

types.name: CrossAccountNrdbResultContainer
types.description:
A data structure that contains the results of the multi account NRDB query along
with other capabilities that enhance those results.

Direct query results are available through `results`, `totalResult` and
`otherResult`. The query you made is accessible through `nrql`, along with
`metadata` about the query itself.

fields.name: currentResults
fields.description: In a `COMPARE WITH` query, the `currentResults` contain the results for the current comparison time window.

fields.name: metadata
fields.description: Metadata about the query and result.

fields.name: nrql
fields.description: The [NRQL](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/insights/nrql-new-relic-query-language/nrql-resources/nrql-syntax-components-functions) query that was executed to yield these results.

fields.name: otherResult
fields.description:
In a `FACET` query, the `otherResult` contains the aggregates representing the events _not_
contained in an individual `results` facet.

fields.name: previousResults
fields.description: In a `COMPARE WITH` query, the `previousResults` contain the results for the previous comparison time window.

fields.name: queryProgress
fields.description: Metadata about the execution of an asynchronous NRQL query.

fields.name: rawResponse
fields.description: The raw query results exactly as they are returned from NRDB. NerdGraph provides no additional transformation.

fields.name: results
fields.description: The query results. This is a flat list of objects who's structure matches the query submitted.

fields.name: totalResult
fields.description:
In a `FACET` query, the `totalResult` contains the aggregates representing _all_ the events,
whether or not they are contained in an individual `results` facet.

fields.name: userSearch
fields.description:
Search for users using a custom query.
 If no query is provided, returns all visible users.
 NOTE: this API only supports users in the New Relic One user model.

args.name: cursor
args.description: The cursor to fetch paginated user search results.

args.name: query
args.description:
The user search query takes 1 argument `scope` that takes in various arguments. 
 `userIds` is only an exact match while the rest of the arguments can search for an exact or fuzzy match.

types.name: UsersUserSearchQuery
types.description: Query object for UserSearch.

inputFields.name: scope
inputFields.description: The scope to filter the search response by.

types.name: UsersUserSearchScope
types.description: Different scopes that can be used to filter the returned users.

inputFields.name: email
inputFields.description: Filter by string that will partially match a User's `email`.  Same as `name` it will partially match and case is ignored.

inputFields.name: name
inputFields.description: Filter by string that will partially match a User's `name`. So argument `name='Ste'` will match `name='Steve'` and case is ignored so `name='Koester'` would also match.

inputFields.name: search
inputFields.description: Will match both a User's `email` and `name`.  So argument `search='ple'`  will match `name='Johnny Appleseed'` and `email='mary@example.com'`.

inputFields.name: userIds
inputFields.description: List of 1 or more userIds to filter by. Will only return data for users with ids that match the full ID, no partial matching. (so 2 ids provided will yield at most 2 users)

types.name: UsersUserSearchResult
types.description: The result object for UserSearch.

fields.name: nextCursor
fields.description: The cursor for the next page.

fields.name: totalCount
fields.description:
The total number of users found.
 Note: Not necessarily the same as number of users returned, due to pagination.

fields.name: users
fields.description: Set of all users returned from the query.

fields.name: installationCreateRecipeEvent
fields.description:
Creates a new recipe event.
- A recipe event is created on behalf of the newrelic-cli whenever the CLI attempts to install the infrastructure-agent, for example.
- A recipe event is appended to any existing recipe events, if there are any present in the cache.

fields.name: taggingAddTagsToEntity
fields.description:
Adds the provided tags to your specified entity, without deleting existing ones.
 The maximum number of tag-values per entity is 100; if the sum of existing and new tag-values if over the limit this mutation will fail.

 For details and mutation examples, visit [our docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/nerdgraph/examples/nerdgraph-tagging-api-tutorial).

args.name: guid
args.description: The guid of the new entity.

args.name: tags
args.description: An array of key-values pairs to represent a tag. For example:  Team:TeamName.

fields.name: taggingDeleteTagFromEntity
fields.description:
Delete specific tag keys from the entity.

 For details and mutation examples, visit [our docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/nerdgraph/examples/nerdgraph-tagging-api-tutorial).

args.name: guid
args.description: The guid of the existing entity.

args.name: tagKeys
args.description: An array of keys that have to be deleted. For example: ['Team'].

fields.name: taggingDeleteTagValuesFromEntity
fields.description:
Delete specific tag key-values from the entity.

 For details and mutation examples, visit [our docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/nerdgraph/examples/nerdgraph-tagging-api-tutorial).

args.name: guid
args.description: The guid of the existing entity.

args.name: tagValues
args.description: An array of key-values pairs to represent a tag. For example: Team:TeamName.

fields.name: taggingReplaceTagsOnEntity
fields.description:
Replaces the entity's entire set of tags with the provided tag set.
 The maximum number of tag-values per entity is 100; if more than 100 tag-values are provided this mutation will fail.

 For details and mutation examples, visit [our docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/nerdgraph/examples/nerdgraph-tagging-api-tutorial).

args.name: guid
args.description: The guid of the existing entity.

args.name: tags
args.description: An array of key-values pairs to represent a tag. For example:  Team:TeamName.

The new settings to use - leave blank any settings you do not wish to modify.

While all settings can be specified here some may not affect your installed agents; depending the language agent and the current version installed. Note: not all settings of your agent are available to be set server-side. 

Please see docs.newrelic.com for more information about the capabilities of individual agents.

[Go agent configuration](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/agents/go-agent/configuration/go-agent-configuration/)

inputFields.description: The desired target for the APDEX measurement of this application.

types.name: AgentApplicationSettingsErrorCollectorInput
types.description: The error collector captures information about uncaught exceptions and sends them to New Relic for viewing. For more information about what these settings do and which ones are applicable for your application, please see docs.newrelic.com for more information about agent configuration for your language agent.

inputFields.name: enabled
inputFields.description: Enable error collector

inputFields.name: expectedErrorClasses
inputFields.description: Prevents specified exception classes from affecting error rate or Apdex score while still reporting the errors to APM.

inputFields.name: expectedErrorCodes
inputFields.description: A comma-separated list comprised of individual and dashed ranges of HTTP status codes to be marked as expected and thus prevented from affecting error rate or Apdex score.

inputFields.name: ignoredErrorClasses
inputFields.description: Specified exception class names will be ignored and will not affect error rate or Apdex score, or be reported to APM.

inputFields.name: ignoredErrorCodes
inputFields.description: A comma-separated list comprised of individual and dashed ranges of HTTP status codes that should not be treated as errors.

types.name: AgentApplicationSettingsErrorCollectorHttpStatus
types.description: A list of HTTP status codes and/or status code ranges, such as "404" or "500-599"

types.name: AgentApplicationSettingsSlowSqlInput
types.description: In APM, when transaction traces are collected, there may be additional Slow query data available.

inputFields.name: enabled
inputFields.description: Whether or not slow_sql is enabled.

types.name: AgentApplicationSettingsThreadProfilerInput
types.description: Settings for the thread profiler.

inputFields.name: enabled
inputFields.description: Is thread profiling enabled for this application?

types.name: AgentApplicationSettingsTracerTypeInput
types.description: Input object for setting the type of tracing performed.

inputFields.name: value
inputFields.description: The type of tracing being done.

types.name: AgentApplicationSettingsTracer
types.description: The type of tracing being done.

enumValues.name: NONE
enumValues.description: both cross application & distributed tracing disabled

types.name: AgentApplicationSettingsTransactionTracerInput
types.description: Fields related to transaction traces and data collection for traces.

inputFields.name: captureMemcacheKeys
inputFields.description: Enable or disable the capture of memcache keys from transaction traces.

inputFields.name: enabled
inputFields.description: If true, this enables the Transaction Tracer feature, enabling collection of transaction traces.

inputFields.name: explainEnabled
inputFields.description: If true, enables the collection of explain plans in transaction traces. This setting will also apply to explain plans in slow SQL traces if slow_sql.explain_enabled is not set separately.

inputFields.name: explainThresholdType
inputFields.description: Relevant only when explain_enabled is true. Can be set to automatic configuration (APDEX_F) or manual (see explainThresholdValue).

inputFields.name: explainThresholdValue
inputFields.description: Threshold (in seconds) above which the agent will collect explain plans. Relevant only when explain_enabled is true and explainThresholdType is set to VALUE.

inputFields.name: logSql
inputFields.description: Set to true to enable logging of queries to the agent log file instead of uploading to New Relic. Queries are logged using the record_sql mode.

inputFields.name: recordSql
inputFields.description: Obfuscation level for SQL queries reported in transaction trace nodes.

inputFields.name: stackTraceThreshold
inputFields.description: Specify a threshold in seconds. The agent includes stack traces in transaction trace nodes when the stack trace duration exceeds this threshold.

inputFields.name: transactionThresholdType
inputFields.description: Relevant only when TransactionTracer is enabled. Can be set to automatic configuration (APDEX_F) or manual (see TransactionThresholdValue).

inputFields.name: transactionThresholdValue
inputFields.description: Threshold (in seconds) that transactions with a duration longer than this threshold are eligible for transaction traces.  Relevant only when Transaction Tracer is enabled and transaction_threshold_type is set to VALUE.

types.name: AgentApplicationSettingsThresholdTypeEnum
types.description: Determines whether a threshold is statically configured or dynamically configured.

enumValues.name: APDEX_F
enumValues.description: Configures the threshold to be 4 times the value of APDEX_T

enumValues.name: VALUE
enumValues.description: Threshold will be statically configured via the corresponding "value" field.

types.name: AgentApplicationSettingsRecordSqlEnum
types.description:
Obfuscation level for SQL queries reported in transaction trace nodes.

When turned on, the New Relic agent will attempt to remove values from SQL qeries.

For example:

```
SELECT * FROM Table WHERE ssn='123-45-6789'
```

might become:

```
SELECT * FROM Table WHERE ssn=?
```

This can behave differently for differnet applications and frameworks, please test for your specific case.
Note: RAW collection is not campatible with High Security mode and cannot be set if your agent is running in that mode.

enumValues.name: OBFUSCATED
enumValues.description: This is the default value. This setting strips string literals and numeric sequences from your queries and replaces them with the ? character. For example: the query select * from table where ssn='123-45-6789' would become select * from table where ssn=?.

enumValues.name: OFF
enumValues.description: Query collection is turned off entirely.

enumValues.name: RAW
enumValues.description: If you are confident that full query data collection will not impact your data security or your users' privacy, you can change the setting to Raw, which will record all query values. NOTE: 'Raw' is not permitted when 'High security mode' is enabled.

types.name: AlertsMutingRuleConditionInput
types.description: A condition which describes how to target a New Relic Alerts Violation.

inputFields.name: attribute
inputFields.description:
The attribute on a violation. Expects one of:

* **accountId** - The account id
* **conditionId** - The alert condition id
* **conditionName** - The alert condition name
* **conditionRunbookUrl** - The alert condition's runbook url
* **conditionType** - The alert condition type, such as `metric`
* **entity.guid** - The entity GUID
* **nrqlEventType** - The NRQL event type
* **nrqlQuery** - The NRQL query string
* **policyId** - The alert policy id
* **policyName** - The alert policy name
* **product** - The target product (e.g., `SYNTHETICS`)
* **tags.<NAME>** - Arbitrary tags associated with some entity (e.g., FACET from a NRQL query, for example `tags.appName` or `tags.host`)
* **targetId** - The ID of the alerts target
* **targetName** - The name of the alerts target

inputFields.name: operator
inputFields.description: The operator used to compare the attribute's value with the supplied value(s).

inputFields.name: values
inputFields.description: The value(s) to compare against the attribute's value.

types.name: AlertsMutingRuleScheduleInput
types.description: The time window when the MutingRule should actively mute violations.

inputFields.name: endRepeat
inputFields.description:
The datetime stamp when the MutingRule schedule should stop repeating.
This is in local ISO 8601 format without an offset.

Example: `'2020-07-10T15:00:00'`

Note: Either `endRepeat` or `repeatCount` should be used to end a MutingRule schedule.
Both fields should not be provided together.

inputFields.name: endTime
inputFields.description:
The datetime stamp representing when the MutingRule should end.
This is in local ISO 8601 format without an offset.

Example: `'2020-07-10T15:00:00'`

inputFields.name: repeat
inputFields.description:
The frequency the MutingRule schedule repeats.
If the MutingRule repeats `WEEKLY`, be sure to set `weeklyRepeatDays`.
If the MutingRule does not repeat, use `null`.

Example: `DAILY`

inputFields.name: repeatCount
inputFields.description:
The number of times the MutingRule schedule should repeat.

Note: Either `repeatCount` or `endRepeat` should be used to end a MutingRule schedule.
Both fields should not be provided together.

inputFields.name: startTime
inputFields.description:
The datetime stamp representing when the MutingRule should start.
This is in local ISO 8601 format without an offset.

Example: `'2020-07-08T14:30:00'`

inputFields.name: timeZone
inputFields.description:
The time zone that applies to the MutingRule schedule.

Example: `'America/Los_Angeles'`

See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tz_database_time_zones.

inputFields.name: weeklyRepeatDays
inputFields.description:
The day(s) of the week that a MutingRule should repeat when the repeat field is set to `WEEKLY`.

Example: `[MONDAY, WEDNESDAY]`

types.name: NaiveDateTime
types.description: The `NaiveDateTime` scalar represents a date and time without a Time Zone. The `NaiveDateTime` appears as an ISO8601 formatted string.

types.name: AlertsNrqlConditionBaselineInput
types.description: Input for creating a baseline NRQL condition.

inputFields.name: baselineDirection
inputFields.description: Direction in which the baseline is set on condition.

inputFields.name: description
inputFields.description: The custom violation description.

inputFields.name: enabled
inputFields.description: Whether the NRQL condition is enabled.

inputFields.name: expiration
inputFields.description: Settings for how violations are opened or closed when a signal expires.

inputFields.name: name
inputFields.description: The name of the NRQL condition.

inputFields.name: nrql
inputFields.description: The NRQL query that defines the signal for the condition.

inputFields.name: runbookUrl
inputFields.description: Runbook URL.

inputFields.name: signal
inputFields.description: Configuration that defines the signal that the NRQL condition will use to evaluate.

inputFields.name: terms
inputFields.description: List of critical and warning terms for the condition.

inputFields.name: violationTimeLimit
inputFields.description:
Deprecated - use violationTimeLimitSeconds for full range of values.

Duration after which a violation automatically closes. Default is THIRTY_DAYS.

inputFields.name: violationTimeLimitSeconds
inputFields.description:
Duration after which a violation automatically closes in seconds.
Accepts values between 300 seconds (5 minutes) and 2592000 seconds (30 days).

Default is 3 days (259200 seconds).

types.name: AlertsNrqlBaselineDirection
types.description: Direction for a baseline NRQL condition.

types.name: AlertsNrqlConditionExpirationInput
types.description: Settings for how violations are opened or closed when a signal expires.

inputFields.name: closeViolationsOnExpiration
inputFields.description: Whether to close all open violations when the signal expires. Defaults to true.

inputFields.name: expirationDuration
inputFields.description: The amount of time (in seconds) to wait before considering if the signal has been lost. Max value of 172800 (48 hours).

inputFields.name: openViolationOnExpiration
inputFields.description: Whether to create a new "lost signal" violation to capture that the signal expired. Defaults to false.

types.name: AlertsNrqlConditionQueryInput
types.description:
Information for generating the condition NRQL query.
The output of data from this NRQL query will be compared to the condition terms to detect violations.

inputFields.name: evaluationOffset
inputFields.description:
Deprecated; superseded by `signal.aggregationMethod` with `signal.aggregationDelay` or `signal.aggregationTimer`.

By default, we evaluate the NRQL query in one-minute time windows. Start time depends on the value you select in the NRQL condition's `evaluationOffset`. Evaluation offset cannot be greater than 60 minutes.

This value is the number of time windows we look back at the aggregated.

Example: With an `evaluationOffset` of 3, the NRQL time window applied to your query will be:

`SINCE 3 minutes ago UNTIL 2 minutes ago`

inputFields.name: query
inputFields.description: NRQL syntax that defines the query.

types.name: AlertsNrqlConditionSignalInput
types.description: Configuration that defines the signal that the NRQL condition will use to evaluate.

inputFields.name: aggregationDelay
inputFields.description:
How long we wait for data that belongs in each aggregation window. Depending
on your data, a longer delay may increase accuracy but delay notifications.

Use `aggregationDelay` with the `EVENT_FLOW` and `CADENCE` methods. The maximum
delay is **1200 seconds** (20 minutes) when using `EVENT_FLOW` and **3600 seconds**
(60 minutes) when using `CADENCE`. In both cases, the minimum delay is **0 seconds**
and the default is **120 seconds**.

When using `aggregationDelay`, do **not** use `evaluationOffset`.

inputFields.name: aggregationMethod
inputFields.description:
The method that determines when we consider an aggregation window to be complete
so that we can evaluate the signal for violations. Default is `EVENT_FLOW`.

When using any `aggregationMethod`, do **not** use `evaluationOffset`.

When using the `aggregationMethod` with `EVENT_TIMER`, use `aggregationTimer`.
For `EVENT_FLOW` and `CADENCE`, use `aggregationDelay`.

inputFields.name: aggregationTimer
inputFields.description:
How long we wait after each data point arrives to make sure we've processed
the whole batch.

Use `aggregationTimer` with the `EVENT_TIMER` method. The timer value can range
from **5 seconds** to **1200 seconds** (20 minutes); the default is **60 seconds**.

When using `aggregationTimer`, do **not** use `evaluationOffset`.

inputFields.name: aggregationWindow
inputFields.description:
Aggregation window controls the duration of the time window used to evaluate the NRQL query, in seconds.
The value must be at least 30 seconds, and no more than 15 minutes (900 seconds). Default is 60 seconds.

inputFields.name: evaluationOffset
inputFields.description:
Deprecated; superseded by `signal.aggregationMethod` with `signal.aggregationDelay` or `signal.aggregationTimer`.

By default, we evaluate the NRQL query in one-minute time windows. The start time depends on the value you select in the NRQL condition's `evaluationOffset`. Evaluation offset cannot be greater than 60 minutes.

This value is the number of time windows we look back at the aggregated data.

Example: With an `evaluationOffset` of 3 and a 1 minute aggregation window, the NRQL time window applied to your query will be:

`SINCE 3 minutes ago UNTIL 2 minutes ago`

inputFields.name: fillOption
inputFields.description:
Option that determines the type of value that should be used to fill gaps (empty windows). Defaults to STATIC.

Outlier NRQL conditions may only use NONE.

inputFields.name: fillValue
inputFields.description: If using the static fill option, this the value used for filling. Defaults to 0.

inputFields.name: slideBy
inputFields.description:
This setting gathers data in overlapping time windows to smooth the chart line, making it easier to spot trends.

The `slideBy` value is specified in seconds and must be **smaller than** and **a factor of** the `aggregationWindow`.

Cannot be used with:
- Outlier NRQL conditions

types.name: AlertsNrqlDynamicConditionTermsInput
types.description: NRQL condition terms determine when a violation will be opened.

inputFields.name: operator
inputFields.description: Operator used to compare against the threshold.

inputFields.name: priority
inputFields.description: Priority determines whether notifications will be sent for violations or not.

inputFields.name: threshold
inputFields.description: Value that triggers a violation.

inputFields.name: thresholdDuration
inputFields.description:
The duration, in seconds, that the threshold must violate in order to create a violation.
Value must be within 120-3600 seconds and a multiple of the aggregation window for baseline and outlier conditions.
(Default aggregation window duration is 60 seconds.)

inputFields.name: thresholdOccurrences
inputFields.description: How many data points must be in violation for the specified threshold duration.

types.name: AlertsNrqlDynamicConditionTermsOperator
types.description: Operator used to compare against the threshold for `NrqlConditions`. Only `ABOVE` is allowed for baseline and outlier NRQL conditions.

enumValues.name: ABOVE
enumValues.description: For comparing values above a threshold.

types.name: AlertsNrqlConditionUpdateQueryInput
types.description:
Information for generating the condition NRQL query.
Output from this NRQL query will be compared to the condition terms to detect violations.

inputFields.name: evaluationOffset
inputFields.description:
Deprecated; superseded by `signal.aggregationMethod` with `signal.aggregationDelay` or `signal.aggregationTimer`.

By default, we evaluate the NRQL query in one-minute time windows. Start time depends on the value you select in the NRQL condition's `evaluationOffset`. Evaluation offset cannot be greater than 60 minutes.

This value is the number of time windows we look back at the aggregated data.

Example: With an `evaluationOffset` of 3, the NRQL time window applied to your query will be:

`SINCE 3 minutes ago UNTIL 2 minutes ago`

inputFields.name: query
inputFields.description: NRQL syntax that defines the query.

inputFields.description:
Deprecated - use `signal.slideBy` instead.

Function used to aggregate the NRQL query value(s) for comparison to the `terms.threshold`. When the result of this aggregate surpasses the `terms.threshold`, a violation is opened.

types.name: AlertsNrqlConditionTermsInput
types.description: NRQL condition terms determine when a violation will be opened.

inputFields.name: operator
inputFields.description: Operator used to compare against the threshold.

inputFields.name: priority
inputFields.description: Priority determines whether notifications will be sent for violations or not.

inputFields.name: threshold
inputFields.description: Value that triggers a violation.

inputFields.name: thresholdDuration
inputFields.description:
The duration, in seconds, that the threshold must violate for in order to create a violation.
This value must be within 60-7200 seconds and must be a multiple of the aggregation window.
(Default aggregation window duration is 60 seconds.)

inputFields.name: thresholdOccurrences
inputFields.description: How many data points must be in violation for the specified thresholdDuration.

types.name: AlertsNrqlStaticConditionValueFunction
types.description:
Deprecated.  By default, condition is evaluated based on each query's returned value.  To aggregate data in time "windows", use `signal.slideBy`.

Function used to aggregate the NRQL query value(s) for comparison to the `terms.threshold`. When the result of this aggregate surpasses the `terms.threshold`, a violation will be opened.

enumValues.name: SINGLE_VALUE
enumValues.description: Condition is evaluated based on each query's returned value.

enumValues.name: SUM
enumValues.description: Condition is evaluated based on the sum of each query's returned values over the specified thresholdDuration.

fields.name: nrdbQuery
fields.description:
Make an `Entity` scoped query to NRDB with a NRQL string.

A relevant `WHERE` clause will be added to your query to scope data to the entity in question.

See the [NRQL Docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/insights/nrql-new-relic-query-language/nrql-resources/nrql-syntax-components-functions) for more information about generating a query string.

args.name: async
args.description:
When true, the query will begin asynchronous resolution after the allotted `timeout`. Include `queryProgress` fields in your GraphQL query to receive the information you will need to poll the `nrdbQueryProgress` field for the results of your async NRQL query.

See [this page](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/nerdgraph/examples/async-queries-nrql-tutorial) for additional asynchronous query documentation.

args.name: nrql
args.description: The [NRQL](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/insights/nrql-new-relic-query-language/nrql-resources/nrql-syntax-components-functions) query string.

args.name: options
args.description: Additional options for NRQL queries.

args.name: timeout
args.description:
The timeout we will apply to the NRQL Query. The value will be clamped to between 5 and 120 seconds and defaults to 5 seconds.

For `async` queries, if the query is still incomplete after this amount of time, resolution will become asynchronous and return `queryProgress` data if requested.

fields.name: nrdbQueryProgress
fields.description:
Poll for the results of a previously-executed asychronous NRDB query.

The `queryId` is available in the `queryProgress` data returned by the original asynchronous query.

See [this page](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/nerdgraph/examples/async-queries-nrql-tutorial) for additional asynchronous query documentation.

args.name: queryId
args.description: A token for retrieving the results of a previously executed asynchronous query.

types.name: DashboardWidgetInput
types.description: Widget input.

inputFields.name: configuration
inputFields.description: Typed widgets are area, bar, billboard, line, markdown, pie, and table. Check our [docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/nerdgraph/examples/create-widgets-dashboards-api/#widget-typed) for more info.

inputFields.name: id
inputFields.description: ID of the widget. If null, a new widget will be created and added to a dashboard.

inputFields.name: layout
inputFields.description: The widget's position and size in the dashboard.

inputFields.name: linkedEntityGuids
inputFields.description: Entities related to the widget. Currently only supports one Dashboard entity guid, but may allow other cases in the future.

inputFields.name: rawConfiguration
inputFields.description: Untyped widgets are all other widgets, such as bullet, histogram, inventory, etc. Check our [docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/nerdgraph/examples/create-widgets-dashboards-api/#widget-untyped) for more info.

inputFields.name: title
inputFields.description: A title for the widget.

inputFields.name: visualization
inputFields.description: Specifies how this widget will be visualized. If null, the WidgetConfigurationInput will be used to determine the visualization.

types.name: DashboardPermissions
types.description: Permissions that represent visibility & editing.

enumValues.name: PRIVATE
enumValues.description: Only you can see the dashboard. Everything but the metadata is hidden.

enumValues.name: PUBLIC_READ_ONLY
enumValues.description: All users are able to see the dashboard, but only you have full rights to work with the dashboard. Other users can access the dashboard but are not able to edit or delete it, although they can duplicate it.

enumValues.name: PUBLIC_READ_WRITE
enumValues.description: All users have full rights to the dashboard.

enumValues.name: CONCURRENT_TASK_EXCEPTION
enumValues.description: Too many concurrent tasks for the same GUID are being sent and we cannot process. Please serialize your requests for the given GUID.

enumValues.name: INVALID_DOMAIN_TYPE
enumValues.description: Domain Type invalid. The decoded domain type from the provided GUID is not valid. Please provide a correct GUID.

enumValues.name: INVALID_ENTITY_GUID
enumValues.description: We could not decode the provided GUID. Entity guid needs to be base64 encoded.

enumValues.description: The given GUID or tag you're looking for does not exist.

enumValues.name: NOT_PERMITTED
enumValues.description: You've attempted to do something your Domain/EntityType is not permitted to do. Its also possible that an api key is required.

enumValues.name: TOO_MANY_CHARS_QUERY_FILTER
enumValues.description: One of the query filters exceeds the character limit.

enumValues.name: TOO_MANY_TAG_KEYS
enumValues.description: The given entity has reached its tag key count limit. You will need to delete existing tags for the given GUID before continuing.

enumValues.name: TOO_MANY_TAG_VALUES
enumValues.description: The given entity has reached its tag value count limit. You will need to delete existing values for the given GUID before continuing.

enumValues.name: UPDATE_WILL_BE_DELAYED
enumValues.description: The changes will be reflected in the entity with some delay

types.name: __Schema
types.description: A GraphQL Schema defines the capabilities of a GraphQL server. It exposes all available types and directives on the server, as well as the entry points for query, mutation, and subscription operations.

fields.name: types
fields.description: A list of all types supported by this server.

fields.name: queryType
fields.description: The type that query operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: mutationType
fields.description: If this server supports mutation, the type that mutation operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: subscriptionType
fields.description: If this server support subscription, the type that subscription operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: directives
fields.description: A list of all directives supported by this server.

types.name: __Type
types.description:
The fundamental unit of any GraphQL Schema is the type. There are many kinds of types in GraphQL as represented by the `__TypeKind` enum.

Depending on the kind of a type, certain fields describe information about that type. Scalar types provide no information beyond a name and description, while Enum types provide their values. Object and Interface types provide the fields they describe. Abstract types, Union and Interface, provide the Object types possible at runtime. List and NonNull types compose other types.

types.name: __TypeKind
types.description: An enum describing what kind of type a given `__Type` is.

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a scalar.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an object. `fields` and `interfaces` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an interface. `fields` and `possibleTypes` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a union. `possibleTypes` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an enum. `enumValues` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an input object. `inputFields` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: LIST
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a list. `ofType` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: NON_NULL
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a non-null. `ofType` is a valid field.

types.name: __Field
types.description: Object and Interface types are described by a list of Fields, each of which has a name, potentially a list of arguments, and a return type.

types.name: __InputValue
types.description: Arguments provided to Fields or Directives and the input fields of an InputObject are represented as Input Values which describe their type and optionally a default value.

fields.name: defaultValue
fields.description: A GraphQL-formatted string representing the default value for this input value.

types.name: __EnumValue
types.description: One possible value for a given Enum. Enum values are unique values, not a placeholder for a string or numeric value. However an Enum value is returned in a JSON response as a string.

types.name: __Directive
types.description:
A Directive provides a way to describe alternate runtime execution and type validation behavior in a GraphQL document.

In some cases, you need to provide options to alter GraphQL's execution behavior in ways field arguments will not suffice, such as conditionally including or skipping a field. Directives provide this by describing additional information to the executor.

types.name: __DirectiveLocation
types.description: A Directive can be adjacent to many parts of the GraphQL language, a __DirectiveLocation describes one such possible adjacencies.

enumValues.name: QUERY
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a query operation.

enumValues.name: MUTATION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a mutation operation.

enumValues.name: SUBSCRIPTION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a subscription operation.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment definition.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_SPREAD
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment spread.

enumValues.name: INLINE_FRAGMENT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an inline fragment.

enumValues.name: VARIABLE_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a variable definition.

enumValues.name: SCHEMA
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a schema definition.

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a scalar definition.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an object type definition.

enumValues.name: FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field definition.

enumValues.name: ARGUMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an argument definition.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an interface definition.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a union definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM_VALUE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum value definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object type definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object field definition.

fields.name: nrdbQuery
fields.description:
Make an `Entity` scoped query to NRDB with a NRQL string.

A relevant `WHERE` clause will be added to your query to scope data to the entity in question.

See the [NRQL Docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/insights/nrql-new-relic-query-language/nrql-resources/nrql-syntax-components-functions) for more information about generating a query string.

args.name: async
args.description:
When true, the query will begin asynchronous resolution after the allotted `timeout`. Include `queryProgress` fields in your GraphQL query to receive the information you will need to poll the `nrdbQueryProgress` field for the results of your async NRQL query.

See [this page](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/nerdgraph/examples/async-queries-nrql-tutorial) for additional asynchronous query documentation.

args.name: nrql
args.description: The [NRQL](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/insights/nrql-new-relic-query-language/nrql-resources/nrql-syntax-components-functions) query string.

args.name: options
args.description: Additional options for NRQL queries.

args.name: timeout
args.description:
The timeout we will apply to the NRQL Query. The value will be clamped to between 5 and 120 seconds and defaults to 5 seconds.

For `async` queries, if the query is still incomplete after this amount of time, resolution will become asynchronous and return `queryProgress` data if requested.

fields.name: nrdbQueryProgress
fields.description:
Poll for the results of a previously-executed asychronous NRDB query.

The `queryId` is available in the `queryProgress` data returned by the original asynchronous query.

See [this page](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/nerdgraph/examples/async-queries-nrql-tutorial) for additional asynchronous query documentation.

args.name: queryId
args.description: A token for retrieving the results of a previously executed asynchronous query.

fields.deprecationReason: This field is experimental! It may change at any time.

fields.name: permalink
fields.description: The url to the entity.

fields.name: recentAlertViolations
fields.description: Recent violations on the entity.

args.name: count
args.description: The desired number of alert violations to be returned.

fields.name: relatedEntities
fields.description: Related entities result with optional filtering.

args.name: cursor
args.description: The cursor to fetch paginated results.

args.name: filter
args.description: Apply an optional filter to the related entities.

args.name: limit
args.description: A limit to apply to the number of relationships returned. Note: this option can only lower the default limits (2000 relationships).

fields.name: relationships
fields.description:
A list of the entities' relationships.

For more information, visit [our docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/graphql-api/tutorials/graphql-relationships-api-tutorial).

args.name: endTime
args.description: Return relationships as they existed in the past. The duration of the time window queried is fixed at 75 minutes.

args.name: filter
args.description: Apply an optional filter to the relationships.

fields.deprecationReason: This field is deprecated! Please use `relatedEntities`.

fields.name: reporting
fields.description: The reporting status of the entity. If New Relic is successfully collecting data from your application, this will be true.

fields.name: serviceLevel
fields.description: The service level defined for the entity.

fields.name: tags
fields.description:
The tags applied to the entity.

For details on tags, as well as query and mutation examples, visit [our docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/graphql-api/tutorials/graphql-tagging-api-tutorial).

fields.name: tagsWithMetadata
fields.description: The tags applied to the entity with their metadata.

fields.name: tracingSummary
fields.description: Look up Distributed Tracing summary data for the selected `EntityGuid`

args.name: timeWindow
args.description: The start and end of the tracing data. Defaults to the last 30 minutes

fields.name: type
fields.description: The entity's type

fields.name: nrdbQuery
fields.description:
Make an `Entity` scoped query to NRDB with a NRQL string.

A relevant `WHERE` clause will be added to your query to scope data to the entity in question.

See the [NRQL Docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/insights/nrql-new-relic-query-language/nrql-resources/nrql-syntax-components-functions) for more information about generating a query string.

args.name: async
args.description:
When true, the query will begin asynchronous resolution after the allotted `timeout`. Include `queryProgress` fields in your GraphQL query to receive the information you will need to poll the `nrdbQueryProgress` field for the results of your async NRQL query.

See [this page](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/nerdgraph/examples/async-queries-nrql-tutorial) for additional asynchronous query documentation.

args.name: nrql
args.description: The [NRQL](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/insights/nrql-new-relic-query-language/nrql-resources/nrql-syntax-components-functions) query string.

args.name: options
args.description: Additional options for NRQL queries.

args.name: timeout
args.description:
The timeout we will apply to the NRQL Query. The value will be clamped to between 5 and 120 seconds and defaults to 5 seconds.

For `async` queries, if the query is still incomplete after this amount of time, resolution will become asynchronous and return `queryProgress` data if requested.

fields.name: nrdbQueryProgress
fields.description:
Poll for the results of a previously-executed asychronous NRDB query.

The `queryId` is available in the `queryProgress` data returned by the original asynchronous query.

See [this page](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/nerdgraph/examples/async-queries-nrql-tutorial) for additional asynchronous query documentation.

args.name: queryId
args.description: A token for retrieving the results of a previously executed asynchronous query.

fields.deprecationReason: This field is experimental! It may change at any time.

fields.name: permalink
fields.description: The url to the entity.

fields.name: recentAlertViolations
fields.description: Recent violations on the entity.

args.name: count
args.description: The desired number of alert violations to be returned.

fields.name: relatedEntities
fields.description: Related entities result with optional filtering.

args.name: cursor
args.description: The cursor to fetch paginated results.

args.name: filter
args.description: Apply an optional filter to the related entities.

args.name: limit
args.description: A limit to apply to the number of relationships returned. Note: this option can only lower the default limits (2000 relationships).

fields.name: relationships
fields.description:
A list of the entities' relationships.

For more information, visit [our docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/graphql-api/tutorials/graphql-relationships-api-tutorial).

args.name: endTime
args.description: Return relationships as they existed in the past. The duration of the time window queried is fixed at 75 minutes.

args.name: filter
args.description: Apply an optional filter to the relationships.

fields.deprecationReason: This field is deprecated! Please use `relatedEntities`.

fields.description: The reporting status of the entity. If New Relic is successfully collecting data from your application, this will be true.

fields.name: serviceLevel
fields.description: The service level defined for the entity.

fields.name: tags
fields.description:
The tags applied to the entity.

For details on tags, as well as query and mutation examples, visit [our docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/graphql-api/tutorials/graphql-tagging-api-tutorial).

fields.description: The tags applied to the entity with their metadata.

fields.name: tracingSummary
fields.description: Look up Distributed Tracing summary data for the selected `EntityGuid`

args.name: timeWindow
args.description: The start and end of the tracing data. Defaults to the last 30 minutes

fields.name: nrdbQuery
fields.description:
Make an `Entity` scoped query to NRDB with a NRQL string.

A relevant `WHERE` clause will be added to your query to scope data to the entity in question.

See the [NRQL Docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/insights/nrql-new-relic-query-language/nrql-resources/nrql-syntax-components-functions) for more information about generating a query string.

args.name: async
args.description:
When true, the query will begin asynchronous resolution after the allotted `timeout`. Include `queryProgress` fields in your GraphQL query to receive the information you will need to poll the `nrdbQueryProgress` field for the results of your async NRQL query.

See [this page](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/nerdgraph/examples/async-queries-nrql-tutorial) for additional asynchronous query documentation.

args.name: nrql
args.description: The [NRQL](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/insights/nrql-new-relic-query-language/nrql-resources/nrql-syntax-components-functions) query string.

args.name: options
args.description: Additional options for NRQL queries.

args.name: timeout
args.description:
The timeout we will apply to the NRQL Query. The value will be clamped to between 5 and 120 seconds and defaults to 5 seconds.

For `async` queries, if the query is still incomplete after this amount of time, resolution will become asynchronous and return `queryProgress` data if requested.

fields.name: nrdbQueryProgress
fields.description:
Poll for the results of a previously-executed asychronous NRDB query.

The `queryId` is available in the `queryProgress` data returned by the original asynchronous query.

See [this page](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/nerdgraph/examples/async-queries-nrql-tutorial) for additional asynchronous query documentation.

args.name: queryId
args.description: A token for retrieving the results of a previously executed asynchronous query.
